description: From on- +‎ rush. Compare Middle English onresen (“to rush upon; attack”), from Old English onrǣsan (“to rush, rush on”); Old English onrǣs (“an onrush, assault, attack”).

entries.meaning: A forceful rush or flow forward.
examples: The love within us and the love without
Are mixed, confounded; if we are loved or love,
We scarce distinguish. So, with other power.
Being acted on and acting seem the same:
In that first onrush of life’s chariot-wheels,
We know not if the forests move or we.

verbs.description: onrush (third-person singular simple present onrushes, present participle onrushing, simple past and past participle onrushed)

entries.meaning: To rush or flow forward forcefully.
